title: Working with models
text:
Models and visualizations

Adding regression and smoothing lines to ggplot visualizations

Describing, fitting, and using models

Linear regression
Other regression
Generalized additive models
LOESS smooths

title: Working with models
text:
Examples

Linear regression
Polynomial model
Quantile regression (fitting line to medians or other quantiles)
Generalized additive model (piecewise splines)
LOESS (local linear and quadratic regression)
Putting multiple smooths on one plot
Smooths on facetted plots

title: Working with models
text:
Start with a basic graph

mpg |> mutate(city_l100km = 235.214583 / cty) |>
   ggplot(aes(x =displ, y= city_l100km)) + geom_point() +
   labs(x = "Engine displacement (L)",
        y = "Fuel economy, city (L/100km)") + my_theme

title: Working with models
text:
Add a regression line

p + geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ x)

title: Working with models
section: Add a regression line for each group
text:
Add a regression line for each group

p + geom_smooth(aes(color = factor(cyl)), method = "lm", formula = y ~ x)

title: Working with models
text:
Polynomial regression

p + geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ poly(x,2))

title: Working with models
text:
Quantile regression

p + geom_quantile(method = "rqss", formula = y ~ x,
                  quantiles = c(0.1, 0.5, 0.9))



Requires package quantreg

title: Working with models
text:
Generalized additive model

p + geom_smooth(method = "lm", 
                formula = y ~ splines::bs(x, df = 5))

title: Working with models
text:
Generalized additive model

p + geom_smooth(method = "gam", 
                formula = y ~ s(x, bs="cs"))

title: Working with models
text:
LOESS

p + geom_smooth(method = "loess", 
                formula = y ~ x)

title: Working with models
text:
LOESS

p + geom_smooth(method = "loess", formula = y ~ x,
                span = 0.3)

title: Working with models
section: Putting multiple smooths on one plot
text:
Putting multiple smooths on one plot

p + geom_smooth(aes(color = "Linear"), method = "lm", se=FALSE) +
    geom_smooth(aes(color = "GAM"), method = "gam", se=FALSE) +
    geom_smooth(aes(color = "LOESS"), method = "loess", formula = y ~ x, se=FALSE) +
    labs(color = "Type")

title: Working with models
text:
Smooths on facetted plots

p + geom_smooth(method = "lm", se=FALSE, formula = y ~ x) +
  facet_wrap( ~ class)

title: Working with models
text:
Other customizations

p + geom_smooth(method = "lm", se=TRUE, 
                fullrange = TRUE, level = 0.50) + xlim(1,8)

title: Working with models
section: Modelling x as a function of y
text:
Modelling x as a function of y

p + geom_smooth(method = "loess", formula = y ~ x, orientation = "y")

title: Working with models
section: Modelling x as a function of y
text:
Modelling x as a function of y

p + geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ x, orientation = "y") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", formula = y ~ x, color = "red")

title: Working with models
text:
Summary

Regression lines (based on a model) and “smooths” (no simple model) can be used to draw attention to patterns in data
We are using smooths for their visual effect
Logical reasoning for the lines you draw is important (next lessons)

title: Working with models
text:
Further reading

Course notes
Healy Chapter 6. Work with models.

title: GAM and LOESS models
text:
GAM and LOESS models

Describing, fitting, and using models
No (simple, easily understood) model coefficients
Calculating residuals
Making predictions: point estimates and standard errors or confidence intervals

title: GAM and LOESS models
text: Start with a basic graph

title: GAM and LOESS models
text:
Fit a cubic spline

library(mgcv)
m1 <- gam( mean_temp ~ s(year_day, bs="cs"), data = hfx)
summary(m1)


Family: gaussian 
Link function: identity 

Formula:
mean_temp ~ s(year_day, bs = "cs")

Parametric coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)   7.0590     0.1415   49.89   <2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Approximate significance of smooth terms:
              edf Ref.df     F p-value    
s(year_day) 8.868      9 429.1  <2e-16 ***
---

title: GAM and LOESS models
GAM and LOESS models
text:
Graph “smooth” term

confint(m1, "s(year_day)", level = 0.95) |>
  ggplot(aes(year_day)) +
  geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = lower, ymax = upper), alpha = 0.25, fill="red") +
  geom_line(aes(y=est), size=2, color="red") + 
  geom_point(aes(y = mean_temp - mean(mean_temp)), data = hfx) + 
  my_theme

title: GAM and LOESS models
text:
LOESS smooths

m2 <- loess( mean_temp ~ year_day, data = hfx)
summary(m2)

Call:
loess(formula = mean_temp ~ year_day, data = hfx)

Number of Observations: 717 
Equivalent Number of Parameters: 4.36 
Residual Standard Error: 5.969 
Trace of smoother matrix: 4.74  (exact)

Control settings:
  span     :  0.75 
  degree   :  2 
  family   :  gaussian
  surface  :  interpolate     cell = 0.2
  normalize:  TRUE
 parametric:  FALSE
drop.square:  FALSE

title: GAM and LOESS models
text:
Residuals

augment(m2, se_fit = TRUE) |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = .resid)) + 
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 1) + my_theme

title: GAM and LOESS models
text:
Predictions

new_data = tibble(year_day = seq(1:730))
augment(m2, newdata = new_data, se_fit = TRUE) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = year_day, y = .fitted)) + 
  geom_line(size = 2, color="blue") +
  geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = .fitted - 2*.se.fit,
                  ymax = .fitted + 2*.se.fit), alpha = 0.25, fill="blue") +
  geom_point(aes(y = mean_temp), data = hfx) + my_theme

title: GAM and LOESS models
text:
LOESS with smaller span

m3 <- loess(mean_temp ~ year_day, data = hfx, 
            degree = 1, span = 0.25)
augment(m3, newdata = new_data, se_fit = TRUE) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = year_day, y = .fitted)) + 
  geom_line(size = 2, color="blue") +
  geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = .fitted - 2*.se.fit,
                  ymax = .fitted + 2*.se.fit), alpha = 0.25, fill="blue") +
  geom_point(aes(y = mean_temp), data = hfx) + my_theme

title: Finding data
text:
Where to get data?

R packages
Websites: gapminder, Our World in Data, Tidy Tuesday
Large repositories: Statistics Canada, OECD
Specialized repositories: Many COVID data repositories
Small collections made by individuals
Government “Open data”
Many, many, many more sources: google

title: Finding data
text:
What to look for?

Downloadable spreadsheets, comma separated variables files, text files
R packages to download data
GitHub repositories (and others: pangaea.de, osf.io, and many, many more)
A license or terms and conditions of reuse and redistribution

electricity <- read_csv("static/L19/electricity_use_per_person.csv")
electricity %>% 
  filter(str_starts(country, "[AM]")) %>%
  ggplot(aes(`2010`, fct_reorder(country, `2010`))) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "Electricity use in 2010\n(annual kWh per capita)", y = "") + my_theme

title: PCA: Principal Component Analysis
text:
Plan

What is PCA and why do we use it?
Demonstration with gapminder data in 3 dimensions
More demonstrations

title: PCA: Principal Component Analysis
text:
What is PCA?

A tool for simplifying data sets with many variables down to a small number
Works best with quantitative variables that are partially correlated
Can be used with one or more categorical variables to identify subgroups

Main results are

Spatial pattern of points (with categorical labels)
Directions of principal components along original axes (loadings)
Amount of variation along each PC axis


Be careful with scaling and units

title: PCA: Principal Component Analysis
text:
Example data
Interactive version


Plot made with plot_ly function in plotly package.

title: PCA: Principal Component Analysis
text:
Pairs plot

my_gapminder %>% select(-year) %>% ggpairs(aes(color = continent))



ggpairs is in the GGally package.

title: PCA: Principal Component Analysis
text:
PCA: 2007 data only

pca1 <- prcomp(my_gapminder2 %>% select(-continent), scale=TRUE)
autoplot(pca1, data = my_gapminder2, loadings=TRUE, loadings.label = TRUE,
         colour = 'continent')

title: PCA: Principal Component Analysis
text:
PCA: All years

pca1 <- prcomp(my_gapminder %>% select(-continent, -year), 
               scale=TRUE)
autoplot(pca1, data = my_gapminder, loadings=TRUE, 
         loadings.label = TRUE, colour = 'continent')

title: PCA: Principal Component Analysis
text: Penguins

title: PCA: Principal Component Analysis
text:
Summary

Use PCA to reduce the number of dimensions (variables) in your data
Interpret loadings (arrows and numeric vectors)
Pay attention to the proportion of variance along each principal component
Consequences of scaling variables (or not scaling them)

title: PCA: Principal Component Analysis
text:
Task

Bonus task: Practice the PCA skills in this lesson

title: PCA: Principal Component Analysis
text:
Penguin PCA code

my_penguins_raw = penguins_raw %>% select(-`Sample Number`) %>% 
  select(Species, where(is.numeric) ) %>% na.omit() %>%
  mutate(Species = str_remove(Species, "\\(.*\\)"))
pca2 <- my_penguins_raw %>% select(-Species) %>% prcomp(scale=TRUE)
autoplot(pca2, data = my_penguins_raw, 
         loadings=TRUE, loadings.label = TRUE,
         loadings.label.colour = "black", loadings.colour = "black",
         colour = 'Species') + xlim(-0.15, 0.15) + ylim(-0.15, 0.15)

title: k-means clustering
text:
Plan

What is k-means clustering and why do we use it?
Demonstration

title: k-means clustering
text:
What is k-means?

A tool to place observations in discrete groups
Based on a distance calculated on several variables
You decide how many groups to use (but there is guidance)
There are variations on the algorithm and other methods (not discussed in this course)

title: k-means clustering

title: k-means clustering
text:
When to use k-means?

When the goal is to make categories from continuous variables
Each observation is placed in a cluster

Based on distance between observations, calculated across all variables

Usually best to scale (and maybe transform in other ways) each variable


Select the number of clusters based on partitioning of “sums of squares”

Plan

Why is testing important?
Testing data
Testing code
Examples
Application in this course

title: Checking your work
text: Data error

title: Checking your work
text: Computing error

title: Checking your work
text:
Why is testing important?

Visualizations are powerful and help people draw conclusions
Data errors and misunderstandings can corrupt your work
Mistakes in analysis (summarize, grouping, calculations) can lead to wrong conclusions
Checking (manually and automatically) your work improves confidence
If you return to a project later, or give it to someone else, misunderstandings can lead to misinterpretation

title: Checking your work
text:
Testing data

Were the data read correctly by R (numbers, text, dates, missing values)?
Are the expected numbers of rows and columns present? Is there a way to check?
Are any values impossible? (Negative counts or lengths.)
Changes in units? (Lots of “outliers”) Human-coded numbers (commas, spaces, scales like M, K for millions and thousands)
Spelling errors, abbreviations, or variants? Capitalization. Extra spaces.
Duplicated data?
Date formatting. Times and time zones.

title: Checking your work
text:
How to test data?
Most powerful and easiest to use techniques:

Summary tables: counts, means, ranges
Simple visualizations: histograms, boxplots, scatter plots

Check the “obvious” things.

title: Checking your work
text:
Testing calculations

Test your code on sample or simulated data
Perform a part of the calculation by hand to independently check a result
Positive and negative controls (just like experiments)
Provide a test dataset and correct report for future users to check

title: Checking your work
text:
Summary: testing in this course

We are not routinely testing data or code in this course
You should be aware of the way errors get into analyses and that there are methods for guarding against them
You should do some checking of the data in your term project, but it’s not an assigned part of the work

title: Making outline maps
text:
Map libraries

ggmap (part of tidyverse)

Many other libraries

maps

mapproj for making projections of the Earth’s surface

mapdata with maps of China and Japan

leaflet for drawing raster or tiled maps (next lesson)

title: Making outline maps
text:
Kinds of maps

Coastlines and political boundaries
Natural features (rivers, water bodies)
Points and filled regions on maps
How to represent latitude and longitude from a sphere on a screen?
Tiled maps

title: Making outline maps
text:
A basic map

library(tidyverse)
WorldData <- map_data('world')  
m1 <- ggplot(WorldData, aes(map_id=region)) + 
        geom_map(map = WorldData,
                 aes(x = long, y = lat),
                 fill = "lightgray", colour = "#7f7f7f", 
                 alpha = 0.5, size=0.5) +
  theme_bw()

title: Making outline maps

title: Making outline maps
text:
Colour countries

values <- tibble( region = WorldData %>% pull(region) %>% unique())
values <- values %>% mutate(value = runif(nrow(values)))
m2 <- ggplot(values, aes(map_id = region)) + 
        geom_map(aes(fill = value),
                 map = WorldData,
                 colour = "lightgray", 
                 alpha = 1, size=0.5) +
   expand_limits(x = c(-180,180), y = c(-80,80)) +
   theme_bw()

title: Making outline maps
text:
Add points

library(rnaturalearth)
library(rnaturalearthdata)
library(ggrepel)
canada <- ne_countries(country = "canada", scale = "large", 
                       returnclass = "sf")
sites <- tibble(longitude = c(-81, -80), latitude = c(44, 45), 
                label = c("A", "B"))
m5 <- ggplot(data = canada) +
      geom_sf() +
      geom_point(data = sites, 
                 aes(x = longitude, y = latitude), 
                 size = 4, shape = 21, fill = "darkred") +
  geom_label_repel(data = sites, 
                   aes(x = longitude, y = latitude, 
                       label = label)) + 
  coord_sf(xlim = c(-140,-50), ylim = c(42,65))

title: Alternatives to maps
text:
Plan

When is a map not appropriate for geospatial data?
Tile geometry
Heatmaps with dendrograms
Specialized heatmap for the USA

title: Alternatives to maps
section: Why shouldn’t I use a map?
text:
Why shouldn’t I use a map?

Always think about the purpose
Is geography the most important feature?
Are you showing points or areas?
Will the area of a region complicate interpretation?
Is the spatial extent one dimensional? What could you do with the other dimension?

title: Alternatives to maps
text:
Summary

Maps are very effective for showing points where spatial location is the primary information
To show quantitative data varying along a transcect, a line or dot plot may be better
Colour shows larger/smaller, positive/negative, but does not show quantitative values well
Heatmaps (2 dimensional tiles of colours) can be a good alternative

title: Theme
text: Starting figure

text:
Ready to use themes

p1 + theme_bw()

text:
Ready to use themes

p1 + theme_classic()

text:
More themes

theme_dark, theme_gray, theme_light
From ggthemes: theme_wsj, theme_tufte, theme_fivethirtyeight, theme_economist, theme_clean

title: Theme
text:
All text larger

p1 + theme(text = element_text(size=22))

title: Theme
text:
Sizes for different elements

p1 + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(size=16),
           axis.title.y = element_text(size=18),
           legend.title = element_text(size=16),
           legend.text = element_text(size=18),
           plot.title = element_text(size=21),
           plot.subtitle = element_text(size=20)) +
  labs(x = "Year", 
       y = "Life Expectancy at birth",
       title = "Life expectancy averaged by continent",
       subtitle = "From Gapminder.org")

title: Theme
text:
Other features of text

p1 + labs(title = "Average life expectancy") + 
  theme(plot.title = element_text(family = "serif",
                                  face = "italic",
                                  color = "blue",
                                  size = 30,
                                  hjust = 1, 
                                  lineheight = 2))

title: Theme
text:
Fancy text: ggtext

library(ggtext)
p1 + labs(title = "**Gapminder** data for _life expectancy_<sup>1</sup>",
          caption = "<sup>1</sup>from gapminder.org") +
  theme(plot.title = element_markdown(size = 24),
        plot.caption = element_markdown(size = 13))

title: Theme
text:
Move and redesign the legend

p1 + theme(legend.position = "top",
           legend.direction = "horizontal",
           legend.text = element_text(size = 11, vjust = 0.5),
           legend.title = element_text(size = 12, vjust = 0.5),
           legend.key.size = unit(0.9, "cm"))

title: Theme
text:
Move and redesign the legend

p1 + theme_bw() + theme(legend.position = c(0.03, 0.98),
                        legend.justification = c(0,1),
           legend.direction = "vertical",
           legend.background = element_rect(fill = "transparent"),
           legend.text = element_text(size = 10, vjust = 0.5),
           legend.title = element_blank(),
           legend.key.size = unit(0.8, "cm")) + 
  guides(color = guide_legend(ncol = 3))

title: Theme
text:
Formatting numbers on scales

p1 + scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::dollar) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) + # also comma
  theme(axis.text = element_text(size=14))

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
The goal

cover image

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
Get the data

library(gapminder)
gapminder %>% knitr::kable()

We will make a scatterplot of life expectancy as a function of GDP per capita, for one year only.

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
First Plot
The last year with data is 2007, so let’s take those data and make a scatterplot.

gapminder %>% 
  filter(year == 2007) %>%
  ggplot(aes(y=lifeExp,
             x=gdpPercap)) + 
  geom_point()

title: Recreating a plot step by step
section: Change the x-axis to a log scale
text:
Change the x-axis to a log scale
The figure uses \(\log_2\) with fancy labels (and has an error), but we will be content with simple labels.

gapminder %>%
  filter(year == 2007) %>%
  ggplot(aes(y=lifeExp,
             x=gdpPercap)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  scale_x_continuous(trans = "log2")

title: Recreating a plot step by step
section: Add axis labels and a title
text:
Add axis labels and a title
Clean up the axis labels. I’ll hide some of the code to make room on the screen.

gapminder %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y=lifeExp, 
             x=gdpPercap)) + 
  ... + 
  xlab("Income per person, GCP/capita in $/year adjusted for inflation and prices") + 
  ylab("") + 
  ggtitle("Life Expectancy (2007)")

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
Add colour
We will use the continent name to pick colours.

gapminder %>% 
  ggplot(aes(y=lifeExp, 
             x=gdpPercap, 
             color=continent)) + 
  ...

title: Recreating a plot step by step
section: Make points transparent to highlight overlap
text:
Make points transparent to highlight overlap

  ggplot(aes(y=lifeExp, 
             x=gdpPercap, 
             color=continent)) + 
  geom_point(alpha=0.5) +
  ...

title: Recreating a plot step by step
section: Add a black outline to each dot
text:
Add a black outline to each dot

  ggplot(aes(y=lifeExp, 
             x=gdpPercap, 
             color=continent)) + 
  geom_point(alpha=0.5) +
  geom_point(shape=1, color="black") +
  ...

title: Recreating a plot step by step
section: Match the colour scale to the example
text:
Match the colour scale to the example

  ggplot(aes(y=lifeExp, 
             x=gdpPercap, 
             color=continent)) + 
  ... +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("blue", "green", "pink", "yellow", "red"))

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
Make the points bigger
Scale the size of points using the population of each country.

  ggplot(aes(y=lifeExp, 
             x=gdpPercap, 
             color=continent, 
             size=pop)) + 
  ...

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
Make the points bigger: Part 2
Make the points bigger by setting the maximum size of the points.

  ggplot(aes(y=lifeExp, 
             x=gdpPercap, 
             color=continent, 
             size=pop)) + 
  ... +
  scale_size_area(max_size = 20)

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
Hide the legend

  ggplot(aes(...)) + 
  ... +
  theme(legend.position =
          "none")

title: Recreating a plot step by step
section: Draw a map for the inset
text:
Draw a map for the inset
Get the map data and draw a map. Google a first example.

world <- ne_countries(scale='medium',
      returnclass = 'sf')

world %>%
  ggplot() + 
  geom_sf(aes(fill=continent))

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
Remove Antarctica

world %>% 
  filter(continent != 
           "Antarctica") %>%
  ggplot() + 
  geom_sf(aes(fill=continent))

title: Recreating a plot step by step
section: Match the colours to the plot
text:
Match the colours to the plot

world %>% 
  ggplot() + 
    scale_fill_manual(values = 
          c("blue", "pink", "yellow",
            "green", "red", "black", 
            "green" ))

title: Recreating a plot step by step
section: Remove outlines on countries and make colors transparent
text:
Remove outlines on countries and make colors transparent

world %>% 
  ggplot() + 
  geom_sf(aes(fill=continent), 
          color=NA, 
          alpha=0.5) +
  ...

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
Remove the legend

world %>% 
  ggplot() + 
  ... +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

title: Recreating a plot step by step
section: Clean up the grid lines, white background
text:
Clean up the grid lines, white background
Lots of help from Google to figure this out!

world %>% 
  ggplot() + ... +
    theme_bw() + 
    theme(legend.position= "none",
      panel.border= element_rect(linetype=0),
      panel.grid= element_line(color=NA),
      panel.background= element_rect(fill=NA),
      plot.background= element_rect(fill=NA),
      axis.text.x= element_text(color=NA),
      axis.ticks.length= unit(0, "cm"))

title: Recreating a plot step by step
section: Store the map in an object for later use
text:
Store the map in an object for later use

world %>% 
  ggplot() + 
  ... -> world_map
print(world_map)

title: Recreating a plot step by step
section: Combine the plot and the map
text:
Combine the plot and the map
And add a floating label for Canada.

ggplot(aes(y=lifeExp, 
           x=gdpPercap)) + 
  annotation_custom(grob=
    ggplotGrob(world_map), 
    xmin=12.3, 
    ymin=35, ymax=50 ) +
  
  geom_label_repel(aes(
          label=country), 
      data = gapminder %>% 
       filter(year ==2007, 
        country=="Canada"), 
    color="black", 
    fill="green", 
    segment.size=1, 
    segment.color="green", 
    box.padding=3) +
  ...

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
Adjust the aspect ratio
Use the ratio of width (log units, log2(30000/300)) to height (80-40), scaled to be 1:2 for a wide plot.

gapminder %>%
  ggplot(aes(y=lifeExp, 
             x=gdpPercap, 
             color=continent, 
             size=pop)) + 
  ... +
  coord_fixed(ratio=(1/2)*
                log2(30000/300)/(80-40))

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
How did we do?

cover image

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
Final code and plot

gapminder %>% filter(year == 2007) %>%
  ggplot(aes(y=lifeExp, x=gdpPercap, color=continent, size=pop)) + 
  geom_point(alpha=0.5) +
  geom_point(shape=1, color="black") +
  geom_label_repel(aes(label=country), data = 
                     gapminder %>% filter(year ==2007, 
                                          country=="Canada"), 
                                   color="black", fill="green", 
                   segment.size=1, segment.color="green", 
                   box.padding=3) +
  xlab("Income per person, GCP/capita in $/year\nadjusted for inflation and prices") + 
  ylab("") + 
  theme_bw() + 
  ggtitle("Life Expectancy (2007)") +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("blue", "green", "pink", 
                                "yellow", "red")) +
  scale_size_area(max_size = 20) + 
  annotation_custom(grob=ggplotGrob(world_map), 
                  xmin=12.3, ymin=40, ymax=55 ) +
  scale_x_continuous(trans = "log2") +
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        text=element_text(size=16))  +
  coord_fixed(ratio=0.5*log2(30000/300)/(80-40)) -> final_plot

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text: Final plot

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
Final map code

world %>% filter(continent != "Antarctica") %>%
  ggplot() + geom_sf(aes(fill=continent), color=NA, alpha=0.5) +
    scale_fill_manual(values = c("blue", "pink", "yellow","green", 
                                 "red", "black", "green" )) +
    theme_bw() + theme(legend.position = "none", 
                     panel.border=element_rect(linetype=0),
                     panel.grid = element_line(color=NA),
                     panel.background = element_rect(fill=NA),
                     plot.background = element_rect(fill=NA),
                     axis.text.x = element_text(color=NA),
                     axis.ticks.length =  unit(0, "cm")) -> world_map

title: Recreating a plot step by step
text:
Libraries used

library(tidyverse)
library(gapminder)
library(ggrepel)
library(rnaturalearth)
library(rnaturalearthdata)
library(rgeos)
